sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: French President Macron and German Chancellor Scholz meet in Berlin, seeking a common response to Russia as fears grow that Moscow could soon attack Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Police investigate the British government over allegations that Prime Minister Boris Johnson attended numerous parties in Downing Street during lockdown.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Prime Minister Boris Johnson attended numerous parties in Downing Street during lockdown. Tragedy at the Africa Cup of Nations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: At least eight people die in a stampede at a stadium in Cameroon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And an abrupt U-turn from Tennis Australia as TESA, supporting the absent Chinese player Peng Shuai, will now be allowed at the tournament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Glad you could join me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: France's Emmanuel Macron and Germany's Olaf Scholz are meeting in Berlin in an attempt to reach a united position on Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We can see live pictures as they meet now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, it comes after EU leaders held talks with US President Biden over video link on Monday night about the rising tensions between Russia and Western nations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Biden afterwards declared that the US is in total unanimity with Europe over Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Worries have been mounting over rising Russian troop numbers and movements along the eastern borders, but Moscow has repeatedly denied that it has plans to invade.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, let's cross now straight to Berlin, where we can speak to reporter Kate Brady.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Great to see you, Kate. To begin with, we know that US President Biden has said that the West now is completely united in what it does facing Russian aggression. But of course, France and Germany are big players in this. Are they completely on the same page?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: France and Germany are big players in this. Are they completely on the same page?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, we heard from German Chancellor Olaf Scholz as he welcomed the French President Emmanuel Macron here in Berlin, saying that he wanted to ensure that everything is done now to de-escalate the situation on the Ukraine-Russian border. But of course, that doesn't mean necessarily that Scholz and Macron see eye to eye on every issue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And that's nothing new when it comes to the great Franco-German relations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And sometimes that is seen also as a positive thing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But if you just look at some of the most recent responses to what's happening on the Ukraine-Russia border right now and some of the wider reaching effects as well, you can see that Germany has been very held, has been holding itself back, especially when it comes to any potential military action and also any export of weapons. At the same time, Germany has now said that it's, it has actually promised a field hospital to Ukraine. If you compare that to the French hospital to Ukraine. If you compare that to the French reaction they've recently promised just in the last couple of days, NATO led troops to Romania to clear up some of what it described as some of the misunderstandings there. So two very different attitudes and a lot to discuss this evening. Absolutely, Kate. I want to dig into some of the, I guess, nitty gritty on this, because when it comes to Germany, they have been, I think, reticent to say explicitly what they will do about Nord Stream 2.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And you spoke about the field hospital.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We know that they won't be sending weapons, for example, to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So can we expect Emmanuel Macron to apply some pressure on those points?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, it's absolutely no secret that Paris' position for a long time has been one that's rather sceptical towards this controversial Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline that runs between Russia and Germany.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We should remind viewers that pipeline is not yet up and running.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And so we've heard from US allies as well saying that this could indeed be used as leverage.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So we could see certainly Macron putting the pressure on when it comes to possibly using Nord Stream 2 as leverage against Russia, should there indeed be any military intervention from Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That said, of course, you know, the difference this time around is that Macron is also not dealing with Scholz's predecessor. It was very clear under Angela Merkel's government that Nord Stream 2 was not about to be halted. But Scholz has said in recent days that all possibilities, all possible sanctions must be discussed and all options are still on the table. So it's not completely ruled out to the extent that it previously was under Angela Merkel's former German government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: All right, reporter Kate Brady taking the temperature there in Berlin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Kate, as ever, great to talk to you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, joining me now is Fabrice Poitier, who is a senior consulting fellow at the Institute of Strategic Studies and is currently at the nato headquarters in brussels welcome to you fabrice good to speak to you as we just mentioned you are there at the nato hq what sense are you getting of the urgency of deploying more troops and arms to the region to support ukraine well of course i'm not speaking for NATO. I'm just there because I had some meetings. I mean, there's the urgency shared all across Europe and the United States. And obviously, everybody is speculating as to what President Putin really has in his sleeve. But the bottom line is obviously that you have an unprecedented level of force deployment by Russian forces at the Ukraine border. And therefore, that requires to show both unity, but also a range of responses that could be deployed if the Russians were to cross certain lines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It's interesting that you just said there that this necessitates a, of course, united response.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But we also know that different members have different stakes in this, when we talk about France and Germany, for example.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So if push comes to shove on this, and Russia does invade Ukraine, will they be in agreement in terms of how to react militarily? That I cannot speculate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But what is clear is that unity is our best weapon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And this is why the EU-US sanctions that have been implemented and held since 2014 have been actually pretty successful in showing to the Russians that we are walking in one step.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: in showing to the Russians that we are walking in one step.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: However, I think what would be extremely powerful is not that President Macron goes to Berlin, but that he goes from Berlin to Moscow with Chancellor Scholz.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I think that would send a very strong message that both France and Germany, and by extent, the whole of NATO is united in speaking with one voice to the Russians. I think this is what we are expecting now, a bit more dramatic diplomacy to really change the terms of the situation, which for the moment are very much in favour of President Putin. How far do you think Europe will go to defend Ukraine?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Because we know that Dmitry Peskov, the spokesman for the Kremlin, has said repeatedly that these movements, these conversations are in fact a provocation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Yeah, well, provocation, I mean, these are the Russian speaking points, so I won't comment on that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But it is obviously, I would say, a steeper proposition to ask European forces to defend a non-NATO, non-EU country like Ukraine than to defend a NATO or an EU country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: That's needless to say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But I think everybody has measured how strategically important Ukraine is.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And I think there's a sense that is growing across European capitals, not only in the U.S., but also across European capitals, that we can't let Ukraine fail and fall under the hands of the Russians. So I do think that if really a dramatic event were to happen, that the Europeans, and at least a majority of them, will mobilize and will be EVENT WERE TO HAPPEN THAT THE EUROPEANS AND AT LEAST A MAJORITY OF THEM WILL MOBILIZE AND WILL BE WILLING TO SUPPORT THE UKRAINIANS. WE TALK ABOUT THAT DRAMATIC EVENT AND I WONDER THEN IN YOUR EYES AND IN THE EYES OF ANALYSTS WHAT EXACTLY WOULD THAT BE? WHAT ARE PEOPLE BRACING FOR IN TERMS OF AN INCURSION? ARE WE TALKING ABOUT TANKS OVER BORDERS? ARE WE TALKING ABOUT WARFARE FROM TRENCHES OR SOMETHING ELSE? WELL I DON'T WANT TO GO INTO SEMANTICS. I THINK IT'S Are we talking about tanks over borders? Are we talking about warfare from trenches?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Or something else?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, I don't want to go into semantics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I think it's whether it's an aggression, being an incursion, invasion, a hybrid.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's an aggression on a sovereign country that is called Ukraine. And, of course, that would be dramatic because it will have a human toll.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But I think President Putin also should know that he will not only be up against Ukrainian armed forces, but he will be up against 45 million Ukrainians who deeply feel Ukrainians and don't want to become Russians or to be part of a greater Russia. And I think this is part of his cost benefit calculus that that he should really think well whatever he wants to do because he will have a whole of a population against him and not just an armed forces all right Fabrice Poitier senior consulting fellow at the International Institute of Strategic Studies good to talk to you thanks for your analysis Good to talk to you. Thanks for your analysis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, in eastern Ukraine, troops are standing by, ready for an attack from across the border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Ukraine's president has told citizens that the situation is stable in the east of the country and that people shouldn't panic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But in the trenches, many Ukrainian soldiers are sceptical about the prospect of peace.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I don't think the Russians started these talks to reach an agreement. I get that Europe is concerned. They have fears and wishes. But Russia is not interested in these talks. They have their own plans and tasks to execute. They won't stop. There's no negotiating with them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Russia has added jailed opposition leader Alexei Navalny and several of his close allies to an official list of terrorists and extremists.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The decision means Navalny's bank accounts are now frozen as part of Moscow's latest crackdown on the opposition and independent media.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The Kremlin critic has been imprisoned in Russia for more than a year after he was arrested last January.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Istanbul is still dealing with traffic chaos after a heavy snowfall brought the city of 16 million people to a near standstill with a number of roads blocked.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Bus services and the international airport, the busiest in Europe, have also been heavily affected.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Schools across Turkey were already closed for the winter holidays and the governor's office asked civil servants to work from home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: In Athens, an operation involving the army, the police, the fire brigade and Red Cross helped thousands of drivers reach safety after being stranded for hours. Volunteers handed out water as well as food and blankets to the drivers in the operation that lasted many hours. A number of Greek islands have also reported heavy snowfall. The situation forced the Greek government to decree two days off. That's Tuesday and Wednesday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: London's Metropolitan Police will investigate alleged social events, Christmas parties and

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: even a birthday get together which took place in the heart of UK government during coronavirus lockdowns. Commissioner Cressida Dick said that the force will be looking at whether COVID-19 regulations were violated at a number of events in Downing Street. A separate inquiry into the gatherings led by civil servant Sue Gray is expected to be released imminently. The deputy leader of the opposition Labour Party has branded the accusations a truly damning reflection on our nation's very highest office. In response to every question asked about the poor conduct, bad behaviour and rule-breaking culture that this government has overseen, the ministers have repeatedly told us Sue Gray is the answer. The terms of reference for Sue Gray set bywestiwn. Mae'r adnoddau o gyfrif ar gyfer Sue Gray, wedi'i roi'n glir gan y Prif Weinidog ei hun, yn glir. Os yw unrhyw ddweuddeg o reoliad sy'n ymddangos fel ddiffyg cyfrifiadol, bydd y peth yn cael ei gyfeirio i'r polis. Felly, mae'n debyg, Brif Weinidog, bod llai o ddiffyg cyfrifiadol wedi cael ei been found in Downing Street.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Boris Johnson says he is willing to be interviewed by the police but continues to claim that he

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: doesn't believe he has broken the law. He told MPs in Parliament that the distraction of the ongoing and now multiple investigations are not distracting him from the business of government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So I welcome the Met's decision to conduct its own investigation because I believe this will help to give the public the clarity it needs and help to draw a line under matters.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But I want to reassure the House, Mr Speaker, and the country that I and the whole government are focused 100% on dealing with the people's priorities including the UK's leading role in protecting freedom around the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well let's take this now straight to London where reporter Taika Enright is standing by.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Good to see you Taika. To begin with the British government is now subject to a criminal investigation. I think it's fair to say that Boris Johnson's chances of retaining the premiership have ebbed and flowed in recent weeks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Where does he stand now?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: JONATHAN CAPEHART, British Prime Minister of the United States, Hi, Helena.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, it's certainly not good news for Boris Johnson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: You did hear the prime minister there welcoming the police investigation, saying it would help draw a line under the social event and party scandal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He could hardly, of course, say otherwise, but, in reality, what prime minister could possibly welcome, not just the scrutiny, but also the spectacle of police investigating what was going on under his very nose.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It does also raise big questions about what information has been passed to police by the senior civil servant who has been investigating all of these parties.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We're getting close to almost 20 of them at the latest stage.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The concern here, after we heard about the police investigation, was that it could somehow delay the report by Ms Sue Gray because the police investigator or the release of that information to the public could jeopardise the police investigation. But the very latest that we're hearing is that it will not delay it because the police have said that it should not interrupt their process. So it sparked fresh calls for Boris Johnson's resignation, not just from the opposition benches, but from some of his critics within his own party. You know, the speculation has been that Conservative MPs who've held back on moving against him so far wouldn't need much more ammunition to be convinced to do otherwise. And as if to add more bad news onto Boris Johnson's in-trade, the reality is that even if the civil servants report doesn't point any smoking gun of evidence at the Prime Minister himself you know no matter how much Boris Johnson wants to move on from this the police investigation is likely to take several more weeks and that will drag on this scandal in the public's conscience for even longer Helena I mean exactly exactly, Tiger.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And the point made by the opposition, by the Labour Party, is that this has now become a distraction.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We've spent so much time talking about whether the Prime Minister lied to Parliament or not, as the case may be, when actually this country has a lot of other serious issues on its plate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It certainly does.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Like many countries around the world right now, coming out of this pandemic, it's dealing with inflation adding to the cost of living, an energy crisis, and not least the management of this stage in the pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And of course, as we've been reporting on earlier, the unfolding situation in Ukraine. Now I have to say the same point is not just being made by Boris Johnson's critics but his supporters too asking the question why are we talking about a birthday parties that happened up to two years ago at the at a time when all this other stuff is going on. Now Helen as you and I both well know, opposition parties here are actually, in truth, rubbing their hands with glee because what they see is a great political adversary, someone who has gobbled up their votes in recent years, is nearing a political cliff edge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And, of course, what he's also doing by clinging on is tarnishing the reputation not just of the people around him, but of the wider Conservative Party.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So the reality is, for those opposition figures calling out the issue of being distracted from the main issues of the day, is that the longer he clings on, the better it is, or could be for them, at the next election.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Eleanor?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Indeed, Tyeke Enright, tonight for us in London. Good to talk to you. Thanks a lot.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: An investigation is underway in Cameroon

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: after a fatal crash at the newly constructed Olembe Stadium in the capital, Yaoundé.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The incident occurred during the Africa Cup of Nations' last 16 tie-up between Cameroon and Comoros.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Thomas Blade now reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: At least eight people are dead following a stampede Cameroon and Comoros. Thomas Blade, NEL reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: At least eight people are dead following a stampede outside a stadium during an Africa Cup of Nations football game in Cameroon. Officials say the crush happened as crowds tried to gain access to Alembe Stadium in the capital, Uande, to watch the host nation, Cameroon, play Comoros in the last 16 knockout match.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: As the police closed the gate, a crowd of people came from behind and I was stuck in it, so I couldn't go back. That's when there were more than 15 people and I was downstairs and God spared me. There were even seven deaths.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: 50,000 people are estimated to have shown up to see the game, but the stadium, with an official capacity of 60,000, had reduced seats due to COVID-19 restrictions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Hospitals in the area are reporting at least 40 people have been injured.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: In the Australian tennis open, the quarterfinals are underway, meaning a Grand Slam final is in

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: touching distance. Women's world number one Ash Barty continued her unstoppable form while in the men's, tensions and temperatures were high in the four hour long slog between Canadian Denis Shapovalov and Rafael Nadal. Heather Donald has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: In the Australian Open, Spain's Rafael Nadal is through to the semi-finals after beating 14th seed Denis Shapovalov in five sets. It was a match full of drama with Nadal needing medical attention while Shapovalov complained he was given longer breaks than usually allowed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Nadal will now face Matteo Berrettini after the seventh seed beat Frenchman Gael Monfils in a rollercoaster five-set victory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It makes Berrettini the first Italian man ever to reach the last four in Melbourne.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: In the women's tournament, Australia's Ashley Barty thrashed Jessica Pegula 6-2, 6-0 to set up a semi-final match against Madison Keyes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Barty who is looking to become the first Australian singles champion in the tournament since 1978 has so far yet to drop a set.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And Keyes swept past French Open champion Barbara Krejcikova to seal her 10th match win in a row and 11th of the new year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's also the first time in seven years that Keyes has reached the Australian Open semi-finals.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Heather Donald, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: In a U-turn, officials at the Australian Open have said that wearing T-shirts in support of absent Chinese player Peng Shui will be allowed. The decision to ban the T-shirts from the tournament had sparked international condemnation from current and former players.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And let's head to Matthew in the Cube now for the latest developments.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Helen, as you say, an abrupt U-turn by Tennis Australia, again in the headlines for actions away from the court.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: This controversy all erupted over the weekend when video showed security officials at Melbourne Park preventing one person from entering wearing a T-shirt that had the words where is Pung Shui. Now the Chinese tennis player has been absent for several weeks after last year she accused a close ally of President Xi Jinping of sexual assault. Since then there has been increased concern about her well-being and Tennis Australia was criticized widely for its stance on people wearing those t-shirts with the words where is Pung Shui. One person was the former Women's World number one and three-time Australian Open champion Martina Navratilova who said on Twitter that the stance was pathetic. Now Tennis Australia initially released a statement saying that the t-shirts had been banned under its policies on political messaging. However they have then relieved those restrictions and lifted them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They've basically said that people will be allowed to wear Where Is Peng Shui t-shirts at Melbourne Park for the Australian Open, as long as they don't congregate in large groups and they don't disturb the spectator experience for others.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Any banners carrying that message will be banned, but that woman in the video wearing that t-shirt has been invited back to continue to watch the tournament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Tennis Australia reiterating that the concern for Peng Shui is one of their primary, and that they are also working with the wider international community.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And after this latest U-turn, Helena reports that activists have been raising around €9,000 and are planning to distribute hundreds of those T-shirts before the Women's Australian Open final due to be taking place on Saturday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Matthew, thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We leave you with a no comment from the Baltic Sea where a group of tourists is embarking on a unique adventure aboard an icebreaker cruise.
